results.title: Embrace
results.creator_credit: Kerreen Ely-Harper, Lindy Macauley, Arts Education, NMIT and Northern Metropolitan Institute of TAFE
results.brief_description:
Embrace, launched in May 2000 by the Minister for Community Services, is the second dance film produced by NMIT (Northern Melbourne Institute of TAFE) featuring dancers with disabilities. Having experience of Loup - a film commemorating the year of the ocean, the artists (in Embrace) further explored the notion of creative expression and different spaces for dancers with disabilities.
Embrace was filmed in the green surroundings of Merri Creek and in the urban landscape of concrete and graffiti at the St Georges Rd bypass. The movements and actions were a direct result of interactions between the dancers and the landscape. The film, filled with beauty, humour and warmth, explores the themes of Hamlet’s soliloquy to be or not to be, namely the themes of betrayal, alienation, desire to escape and the place of dreams in our waking lives.
Embrace was funded by the Australian Council for the Arts, the City of Boroondara, the Department of Human Services and NMIT. The dancers had the opportunity during the production to work with professional artists from diverse backgrounds and expertise.
Embrace was screened at numerous national and international film festivals including the Dance on Camera festival in New York, January 2001. The principal artist, Randal Aitkin, gave a live performance at the screening of Embrace in New York. The significance of that event lies in the fact that the NMIT dance student qualified to perform among the elite of world dancers while overcoming difficulties arising from intellectual disability. Excerpts from Embrace appeared in the Arte programs on the National French and German Television Networks between December 2001 and February 2002.

results.title: Emanuel Feuermann: cellist
results.creator_credit: Ernst Matray, Rudolph Polk, Walter Lowendahl and Artists Films
results.brief_description: Emanuel Feuermann, internationally known cellist, plays Dvorak’s Rondo, Opus 94, Spinning Song by Popper. He is accompanied by Theodore Saidenberg at the piano.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ernst Matray, Rudolph Polk, Walter Lowendahl and Artists Films

results.title: Elvis on tour
results.creator_credit: Robert Abel, Pierre Adigel and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Presents a portrait of Elvis Presley’s life. Shows Elvis speaking publicly for the first time about his life and career; rare footage of his early days; performance of his greatest hits including “Love me tender” and offstage moments.

results.title: Elvis: That's the way it is (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Denis Sanders, Rick Schmidlin and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Elvis: That’s the way it is is a remastered, special edition of the original. This edition includes special features such as the original theatrical trailer and the restored documentary, “Patch it up: The restoration of ‘Elvis: That’s the way it is’”. The documentary is a great introduction to the original picture, providing insights into Elvis the performer, both on stage and in rehearsal. Those who worked and performed with Elvis add an intimacy that only further draws the viewer into the world of Elvis. His masterful performance and ease with the camera makes the feature throughly entertaining for both Elvis enthusiasts and novice alike.

results.title: Elton John live in Australia. Pt. 2
results.brief_description: This concert, in December 1986, before a capacity audience in the Sydney Entertainment Centre, was part of the “Tour de Force” series. Elton and his band are accompanied by the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra under the baton of conductor James Newton Howard. Rated: G

results.title: Elsie
results.brief_description:
Combining 2D art with abstract stylised 3D Elsie’s world is immersive and slightly disturbing as the audience receives a taste of walking in her shoes and seeing with her eyes.
Imagination and reality collide as the race to find the parents she ironically avoids from the evil clutches of her neighbours, the Fenwrights, begins.

results.title: Elizabethan stage: Henry V [study extract]
results.brief_description: The opening sequence of Olivier’s film version of “Henry V”. A remarkable recreation of Shakespeare’s London, showing the first part of the play as it may well have been produced originally on the stage of the Globe Theatre. Olivier’s treatment has been very free, and many amusing sidelights on the actors and audiences of Shakespeare’s day are included. Cast includes Laurence Olivier, Robert Helpmann, Leslie Banks, Quentin Crisp.

results.title: Elementary electricity
results.creator_credit: Roger Brown and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: This video begins with a look at the discoveries of Benjamin Franklin and other early inventors who investigated electricity. Students also learn how Edison and his team relied on the basic principles of electricity in their quest to create a practical incandescent light. The video introduces the concepts of current, conductivity, circuits and magnetism. It also looks at modern electric power systems and how they are based on many of Edison’s ideas. Narrated by Gene Galusha.

results.title: Elie Wiesel: first person singular [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Robert H Gardner, Lives and Legacies Films and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)
results.brief_description: Elie Wiesel is a Nobel Prize-winning author, Holocaust survivor, and human rights activist. Born in the provincial town of Sighet, Romania on September 30, 1928, Wiesel was just fifteen when he, his family and most of the Sighet population were deported to Auschwitz concentration camp in Poland. Of Wiesel’s entire family, only he and his two older sisters survived. In this documentary, made for television, Wiesel is interviewed extensively and discusses his life, experiences of World War II, faith, Jewish background, relationship with his family, in particular his father, and his writings. Actor William Hurt narrates passages from Wiesel’s book ‘Night’, a memoir based on his time spent in Auschwitz as a teenager, decrying the horrors he witnessed first hand. Wiesel also offers observations on such current events as the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks and the Israeli-Palestine war. This documentary utilises black and white photographs of Europe, before and during World War II, and Wiesel’s own photos depicting the stages of his life. With background music by Bach, and a melancholy original score by Leonard Lionnet, this is a thought-provoking and intelligent work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert H Gardner, Lives and Legacies Films and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)

results.title: Sue Ford Moving Image Collection
results.brief_description:
The Sue Ford Moving Image Collection contains the film and video work of Australian artist Sue Ford (1943–2009). The collection includes complete films made during the 1970s and 1980s, including “Faces”, “Time changes” and “Egami”, as well as an extensive archive of 8mm home movies, documentary footage, offcuts, and process-based experiments.

Sue Ford is one of Australia’s pre-eminent photographers and experimental filmmakers. Establishing her photographic practice in the late 1960s, she was the first woman photographer to hold a solo exhibition at the National Gallery of Victoria in 1974. She was a key figure in Melbourne’s art scene throughout the 1970s, where she was involved with the Women’s Art Group alongside artists such as Bonita Ely and Micky Allan. After a time spent in Sydney where she was involved with the Sydney Filmmakers Cooperative, she became a founding member of the feminist film collective Reel Women in the late 1970s.

Most of her films were created during this period and she continued to make photographic and multimedia work throughout the 1990s and 2000s. Her work is held in the collection of the National Gallery of Victoria, the Art Gallery of New South Wales, the Art Gallery of Western Australia, and the National Gallery of Australia.

The Sue Ford Moving Image Collection has been generously donated to ACMI by the Sue Ford Archive, co-directed by her son, Ben Ford, and friend, Joy Hirst.
